awd_titl_txt: Evolution of Dosage Compensation - An Empirical Test using Turtles with Independently Evolved XX/XY and ZZ/ZW Chromosomes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will illuminate the evolution of dosage compensation (DC) by contrasting turtle species with XX/XY, ZZ/ZW and temperature-dependent (TSD) gender determination.   In species like humans, XX/XY females have two copies of genes in the X chromosome and males one because females carry two Xs and males one X and one Y.  An imbalance in gene dosage, such the one caused by the difference in the number of X or Z chromosomes between genders, may reduce fitness or even cause death, without a mechanism to re-establish a balance. Dosage compensation mechanisms (DCM) equalize the activity of genes located in the X or Z (X-linked or Z-linked) between chromosomes, and between males and females. DC is important for normal development, and has consequences for the evolution of genomes and speciation. Yet, DCM diversity and evolution remain unclear. Turtles are ideal to study DCM evolution because XX/XY and ZZ/ZW chromosomes have evolved independently multiple times, and there are increasing turtle genomic resources. To address this puzzle, gene expression is being compared in turtles with contrasting mechanisms of gender determination.  The results will advance our understanding of the diversity and evolution of DMC by illuminating whether there are general rules to DCM across organisms or whether unique solutions evolved independently in each lineage. This project involves undergraduate discovery-based learning by recruiting biology undergraduates, and broadens the participation of underrepresented groups in biology. Undergraduates will be trained in a variety of biological fields, participate in reflection sessions and present their results at scientific meetings. Results will be disseminated via presentations, publications, and a bilingual web-site. 

When XX/XY or ZZ/ZW chromosomes evolve in diploid species, genes are lost from the Y or W (or lose their function) as they degenerate over time due to their lower recombination. This loss means that XY-males carry a single functional copy of X-genes while XX-females carry two copies (likewise, ZW females have one copy of Z-genes and ZZ-males have two copies). Because X- and Z-linked genes are part of genetic networks, the inequality of gene copy number causes an imbalance in transcription which may produce sub-optimal or lethal phenotypes, unless a mechanism existed to re-establish a balance.  In the absence of such mechanism, transcription will differ (a) between genes in these chromosomes and autosomes in XY males (or ZW females), and (b) between males and females for X-genes (or Z-genes). Dosage compensation (DC) is a system to equalize the activity of X- or Z-linked genes to counterbalance the deleterious effects of differential gene copy number. DC re-establishes a balance between these genes and autosomal genes ("chromosome-to-autosome" compensation), and between the genders ("male-to-female" compensation). Mechanisms may balance entire chromosomes (global compensation), other some genes only (local compensation). This project tests the hypothesis that global DC (i.e. chromosome-wide) does not evolve inevitably with the evolution of chromosomes, but instead that DC tends to be local when present (i.e. affecting some genes only), and independent of the size, evolutionary age, and gene content of the chromosomes.  Accordingly, this project it is sequencing microdissected turtle chromosomes, and examining them by arrayCGH, and assessing the expression of these genes via transcriptomics.

por.por_cntn:
TOPIC: In species with sex chromosomes like humans (XX/XY) females have two copies of many genes in the X chromosome and males only one because females carry two Xs and males one X and one Y [organisms like birds have an opposite pattern, with females carrying one Z and one W chromosomes, while males carry two Zs]. An imbalance in gene dosage such as this may reduce fitness or even cause death, unless a mechanism exists to re-establish a balance. Dosage compensation mechanisms (DCMs) equalize the activity of genes located in the X or Z (called X-linked or Z-linked genes) between sex chromosomes and non-sex chromosomes (autosomes), and between males and females. DC is important for normal development, and has consequences for the evolution of genomes and speciation. Yet, DCM diversity and evolution remain unclear. Turtles are ideal to study DCM evolution because XX/XY and ZZ/ZW sex chromosomes have evolved independently.

Intellectual merit— This project was the first study of dosage compensation across taxa with contrasting and independently evolved sex determination within a single vertebrate group, which provided an empirical test of whether XX/XY versus ZZ/ZW, old versus young, or small versus large sex chromosomes differ or not in the way they solve gene dose imbalance, which we found that they do differ in turtles. Results advanced our understanding of the diversity of DCMs that exists in nature and their evolution, as they revealed that while there some general rules to DC across organisms, unique solutions have also evolved independently in various lineages, even within turtles, to deal with the problem of gene dosage imbalance. For instance, we discovered the first case of dosage compensation in eukaryotes that is altered by environmental temperature (in a ZZ/ZW turtle). Results also advanced our knowledge of the development and evolution of phenotypes (phenotypes are all the visible or measurable traits of organisms), particularly sexual development, a process that is incompletely understood, is mediated by sex chromosomes when present and thus affected by their dosage compensation. Specifically, we discovered:

  • new sex chromosomes in turtles, the genes that live in them and their gene expression,
  • susceptibility to temperature in turtles with and without sex chromosomes in the expression of genes that regulate sexual development and of epigenetic machinery genes (genes that regulate the activity of other genes by marking the DNA chemically or altering its folding without changing DNA sequence),
  • the effect of ecotoxic pollutants in the expression and DNA methylation (an epigenetic marking) of genes during the development of the gonads in turtle embryos,
  • the translocation during evolution of genes important for sexual development to the ZW sex chromosomes of turtles which in their ancestor were located in autosomes,
  • and the contrasting dosage compensation of ribosomal RNA genes (genes that code for the cell component where proteins are ensembled) that are harbored by sex chromosomes in some XX/XY and ZZ/ZW turtles, and which consequently, are subjected to the special evolutionary dynamics of sex chromosomes.

The genome assemblies of five turtles were improved or assembled anew (that is, the DNA sequence was decoded and placed in order). A total of 21 manuscripts in peer-reviewed scientific journals were published and 38 presentations at local to international research symposia by the PI, postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students disseminated work funded directly or indirectly by this grant.

Educational activities— 21 undergraduate students and 1 K-12 teacher participated in internships developed to integrate discovery-based learning by immersing interns into research at the PI’s lab (funded by this grant and other sources). Some undergraduates presented their research at scientific meetings and some co-authored the resulting publications. Additionally, 3 postdocs, 5 graduate students, and 11 rotation graduate students participated in the research and training components of this grant. This work helped broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in biology by providing internship opportunities to individuals from underrepresented groups and to their mentors, by mentoring junior women faculty of color, and by engaging preK-12 students during talks about science or about how to become a scientist.
